h1.span: As you are aware, Governor Lee recommended on Wednesday that all Tennessee school systems remain closed for the remainder of this school year.
h1.strong: To coincide with the Governor’s recommendation, I plan to keep our schools closed for remainder of the 2019-2020 school term.
h1.span: I want to extend my gratitude to those who have worked hard the past few weeks to provide our students with meals, resources and instructional materials, and personal contacts letting students and families know that their teachers and schools are still here for them during this very confusing and challenging time.

Last week, the State Board of Education passed policies and regulations that impact grades, graduation requirements, and testing. I am working with principals and supervisors to develop a grading plan for the spring semester that is aligned with these new rules, and the plan will be shared with all teachers and families next week. I take pride in making sure everyone is informed and that our actions are transparent.

As you know, Grainger County Schools developed and implemented a plan to provide our students with the opportunity to continue with their learning, and we hope our families have found these resources useful. Phase I for Grainger County Schools (March 30-April 24) included a student survey for initial parent contact and a week of planning to develop packets, resources, and distribution of these materials and devices. Phase II of our instructional plan will begin on April 30 and end on May 22. In fact, some schools are planning to enter Phase II this upcoming week. I have authorized each principal to contact his/her students as needed to provide updates on grading and/or distribute additional materials to students.

My expectation is that teachers should be making regular, ongoing and personal contacts with each student. Teachers have utilized phone calls, emails, apps and text as well as video conferencing such as zoom to reach out to students. We will also be developing and conducting a follow up survey for Phase II to make sure parents want to continue with the original choice of service –such as online or paper packets – and to give parents that opted out during the first survey the opportunity to receive services during Phase II. We also need to continue to determine if additional devices are needed.

h1.strong: Meals for kids under 18 years of age will resume Wednesday, April 22, 2020.
h1.span: These meals will be available via drive-thru on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM as previously scheduled. Each child under the age of 18 will receive 4 meals – 2 breakfast and 2 lunch. However, the lunches will now be “hot-lunches” at every school except for Rutledge Primary and Rutledge Elementary Schools. Meals will not be served at these two schools. Bag meals will be served at our four remote sites from 11:30AM – 12:00PM each of these three days. The 4 remote sites will not serve hot meals. The 4 remote sites are the parking lots at Bean Station City Hall, Central Point Church, Blaine City Hall, and Thorn Hill Community Center.

It is too early to make a call on whether we can have prom. Prom will be postponed at best. I will say that it does look somewhat doubtful for prom, but I will know more about it in a few weeks. Obviously, if prom is held, it will be much later than previously planned.
h1.strong: As of now I do plan on having graduation but the date, location, and format may change.
h1.span: I don’t anticipate a traditional graduation as we have had in the past. It may be delayed, the venue may change, and the format may be different. In fact, the format most likely will be different. It may possibly be a “drive-thru” graduation. I will be talking to Ms. McElhaney and Mr. Briscoe as well as getting input from students/parents. I will not jeopardize the safety of our students, employees, parents, or community.
I hope you are taking care of yourselves and staying well. Stay positive about the future. We will get through this together.
James Atkins, Director of Grainger County Schools

p.span: Resources and supports are being offered and provided if parents choose to access them, but they are NOT mandatory and will not be used, collected or graded by the school system, however, teachers can be contacted by text, call, email or app, etc., if students or parents have questions or want feedback as they complete activities provided. Resources are provided to support families and not to create additional stress or burden during this unprecedented and extended school closure.
Below is a link to a list of resourses students and parents can use during the school closure.

h3.span: March 30 - April 3: Planning and Device Distribution (Device distribution dates TBA by each school.)
April 13 - 17: Monday and Wednesday- Math and Science for 45 minutes each and 30 minutes of independent reading
Tuesday and Thursday - English/Language Arts and Social studies for 45 minutes each and 30 minutes of independent reading
Friday -CTE 45 mins. each class, Electives such as Art, Music, and others 45 minutes each class, and complete work from M-TH and 30 minutes of independent reading
April 20 - 24: Monday and Wednesday- Math and Science for 45 minutes each and 30 minutes of independent reading
Tuesday and Thursday - English/Language Arts and Social studies for 45 minutes each and 30 minutes of independent reading

span.span: Friday -CTE 45 mins. each class, Electives such as Art, Music, and others 45 minutes each class, and complete work from M-TH and 30 minutes of independent reading
